passages.text: North America Economic Research 29 August 2025

We revised up 3Q GDP from \(1.5\%\) to \(2.5\%\) Profit margins and real wage growth have held up amidst rising tariffs and slowing job growth The Lisa Cook removal goes to court with an uncertain outcome Expect a 75k rise in August nonfarm payrolls and a \(4.3\%\) unemployment rate

After last week's Jackson Hole Symposium cemented expectations for a 25bps rate cut at the September FOMC meeting, the focus shifted back to the economic data. That data suggested growth was holding up this quarter and we raised our 3Q GDP forecast from \(1.5\%\) to \(2.5\%\) . The releases this week brought limited new insight into the labor market, though we will get a clearer picture next week with the release of the August employment report. We look for a 75k increase in total and private nonfarm employment, and a slight rise in the unemployment rate, from \(4.2\%\) to \(4.3\%\) . Although inflation and growth data don't scream out for a rate cut, at this stage it would likely require a significant positive employment surprise to stop the FOMC from moving forward, given their concern about the sharp recent deceleration in job growth.

Even with Jackson Hole behind us, Federal Reserve developments didn't stop, as President Trump made a "for cause" dismissal of Governor Lisa Cook on Monday night, following his call for her to resign last week. Cook immediately filed suit and an initial hearing in DC District Court was held today on the matter Friday. The court has asked for more written arguments to be submitted by Tuesday, though it is unclear when we should expect a decision.

Even if the court rules in favor of Cook, it is not certain that she would be allowed to return to her duties immediately while the government further appeals the case. For example, in the recent Trump v. Wilcox case, the Supreme Court ruled that removed members of the NLRB and MSPB should not be allowed to return to their duties while they continued to litigate against their dismissal. That case concerned whether for cause protections held at all at the NLRB and MSPB, but the same reasoning might be applied to this case.

If the president is successful in terminating Cook soon, then he might be able to install another Board member by next February, when the Board needs to approve the re- appointment of all District Bank presidents. In addition, the Board has the power to "To suspend or remove any officer or director of any Federal Reserve Bank" at any time as long as the cause is communicated in writing. While the president may

soon have a majority of governors who agree with at least some of his views on rate cutting, this does not necessarily imply that these same members- - for example Governor Waller- - would be inclined to break tradition and start mass dismissals of District Bank presidents.

One other issue that this case raises is the establishment of more recent precedent about the process for establishing cause in a "for cause" termination of a Fed governor. For cause dismissals are extremely rare, and they have never been applied to a Fed governor. The Federal Reserve Act does not specify what "for cause" means, though a common interpretation is inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance while in office. Once a clearer template is established for how the executive branch will determine a valid cause, it is possible that this administration, or future ones, might become more prone to using for cause dismissals.

We have been forecasting a 2H25 slowdown for some time, but while employment gains have already decelerated, the other activity data has surprised to the upside, and we now expect real GDP growth of \(2.5\%\) in 3Q, which is in fact an acceleration from the 1H average of \(1.25\%\) . That includes domestic final sales growth of \(2.3\%\) . This raises the question of whether the negative effects of tariffs on growth beyond the first half are not materializing, or whether they are simply set to appear later than we had anticipated. We have not changed our forecasts beyond 3Q, though we are likely to revisit this question following next week's employment report.
Figure 1: Pretax corporate profit margins, NIPAs Percent, sa. Profits are before income taxes but include tariff charges

A notable feature of the recent trajectory has been that corporate profits are still doing well despite limited pass- through of tariffs to consumer prices, and that real wage income is likewise doing considerably better than employment growth. Corporate profits before income taxes for 2Q, which were released this week, showed a surprising \(1.7\% \mathrm{q} / \mathrm{q}\) (not annualized) increase despite rising government tariff revenues. Moreover, profit margins for nonfinancial domestic corporate businesses didn't change quarter- on- quarter. They have com
pressed \(\sim 50\) bps from a year earlier, though are at healthy levels (Figure 1).

Likewise, on a \(3\mathrm{m / 3m}\) basis nonfarm roll growth has slowed to just \(0.5\%\) through July, and yet real wage income over the same period was \(2.3\%\) and nominal income \(4.4\%\) which has helped cushion any shock to consumer spending (Figure 2). Slowing job growth linked to a decline in labor demand should translate into a shorter workweek and lower wage growth, but to date the big job slowdown of the last few months has produced neither of these things.
Figure 2: Nominal wages and nonfarm payroll employment %ch 3m/3m, both scales
Source: BEA, BLS, J.P. Morgan

The key data releases that shaped the latest update to the 3Q forecast were those for durable goods, consumption, trade, and inventories. On consumption, July's \(0.3\% \mathrm{m / m}\) increase was in fact in line with our forecasts, but our auto analysts now expect just a \(1\%\) fall in unit auto sales in August, which improves the chance we could see quicker gains for the rest of the quarter. Consequently, we've boosted our spending forecast to \(2.0\%\) from \(1.5\%\) , slightly faster than the \(1.6\%\) gain in 2Q.
Figure 3: All-industry capex expectations from regional Fed surveys Index, sa

Equipment investment gets a larger upgrade. Between the durable goods report and a widening capital goods trade balance real investment is now tracking close to a \(15\%\) gain, the same as the 1H pace, though given the volatility in some of this data we've tempered that and settled on a still very solid \(10\%\) forecast. Detailed trade data is not out until next week, but we wouldn't be surprised if it shows a renewed surge in

capital goods imports being driven by tech equipment linked to the AI boom. We also finished getting the regional Fed surveys this week, which showed a continued gradual recovery in firm capex intentions (Figure 3).

Speaking of AI, one notable feature of the revised 2Q GDP figures that were released this week was a large upward revision to IPP growth, revised from \(6.4\%\) to \(12.8\%\) , reflecting big upgrades to both software and R&D. Real software investment has risen \(22\%\) annualized in 1H after rising just \(4\%\) in 2024, which may reflect a lift from enterprise spending on generative AI products. Over the first half of this year we estimate that tech- linked capex on data center, power, and communication construction, equipment investment, and software contributed a sizable \(0.4 - 0.5\%\) to annualized GDP growth. That may understate the profits being captured by domestic semiconductor firms who are manufacturing overseas. If we exclude net exports, where the tech trade deficit in goods has ballooned, the contribution to growth is closer to \(1.2\%\) .

July core PCE inflation was in line with forecasts and will not have been surprising to anyone on the FOMC. Core inflation rose \(0.27\% \mathrm{m / m}\) and the over- year- ago pace rose to \(2.9\%\) , up from the recent \(2.6\%\) trough in April and still very much within the narrow range that has persisted since early last year. In other words, inflation appears sticky, with limited progress back toward the Fed's \(2\%\) target. While not all of this data was known at the time of the July FOMC meeting, it's no surprise that meeting minutes showed "many participants observed that overall inflation remained somewhat above" the \(2\%\) target.

In that meeting, "a couple" participants suggested that ex- tariff inflation was already close to target. One of these was likely Governor Waller, who re- iterated this point in a speech this week. While the speech was mostly about labor market risks, Waller noted that "underlying inflation continues to run close to the FOMC's 2 percent target" once tariff effects are taken out. That is based on recent Fed staff work to track tariff- linked inflation.

Perhaps a simpler illustration of this point is that core services inflation, which should be less immediately sensitive to tariffs than goods, rose \(3.5\%\) , which is only moderately higher than the roughly \(3\%\) pace that prevailed from the mid- 1990s to the Great Recession. In the 2010s it dipped further, though arguably to too low a level given core PCE routinely undershot the \(2\%\) target. In contrast, core goods inflation has accelerated to \(1.1\%\) , about \(1.5\%\) - pt stronger than the average in the couple decades preceding COVID.

- Revising up 3Q25 GDP growth in US (2.5%) and EMAX (2.9%) ...  
- ... as global capex strength remains intact  
- US concerns around soft labor demand and sentiment linger  
- Next week: Upbeat August PMI; subdued ISM; soft US jobs and EA HICP

Enormous political pressure is being placed on the Federal Reserve to ease, but their guidance towards a September cut owes primarily to concerns about softening labor demand. At Jackson Hole, Chair Powell echoed our view that weak job growth sends a stall speed alert, and Governor Waller amplified this message this week, arguing that "labor demand may be on the edge of a sharp decline." A near stall in private sector hiring growth is unusual during an expansion and heightens the risk that two potential drags interact in a disruptive fashion. First, this stall often reflects building pressures on firms - through tightening financial conditions or margin compression - that lead to a pullback in spending and hiring. Second, slower labor demand usually depresses household purchasing power and sentiment, promoting consumer caution. Our recent analysis showing that job count revisions tend to be persistent and pro- cyclical, reinforcing these concerns.

We believe a Fed cut is warranted and place the risk of a near- term US slide into recession at an elevated \(40\%\) . But despite weak job growth, wage and profit gains point to continued balanced income growth that is supporting trend- like growth.

- All balanced on the income front. Nominal US gross domestic income was reported to have risen at a robust \(6.8\%\) at last quarter with workers and firms benefiting from this increase (Figure 1). Nominal wage income was up at a \(4.8\%\) and this week's July reading points to current-quarter gains tracking close to this pace. The surprise in the income report was a significant \(6.8\%\) gain in corporate profits last quarter despite rising tariff payments. Domestic non-financial corporate profits are up a modest \(2.5\%\) oya in the face of the tariff tax increase of \(\)163bn\(over the past four quarters, an outcome that has sustained stable profit margins at a near record high. 
- The capex surge continues. This week's material upward revision to domestic final sales growth - from \(1.1\%\) at \(1.6\%\) - was concentrated in business investment. With only a modest slowing from a 1Q25 surge, first-half spending on equipment is up \(15.3\%\) .

The strong rise in July capital goods imports has prompted a revision in our forecast to anticipate a further \(10\%\) ar gain this quarter. While some of this increase can be attributed to front- loading in anticipation of threatened tariff hikes on electronic products, the rebound in intellectual property product spending to a \(9.3\%\) ar reflects a \(22\%\) ar rise in software spending, likely driven by AI software services sales.

Consumer wakes up. US consumers turned cautious this year, but several factors that depressed 1H25 spending growth to an \(0.8\%\) ar likely overstate the underlying behavioral shift. Spending gains this quarter look likely to align with income gains, which are rising at about a \(2\%\) ar.

These developments suggest that softening labor demand is not placing a significant drag on current- quarter US GDP growth, which we revised up this week to a \(2.5\%\) ar. Nonetheless, we view the current balance in US economic performance as delicate and threatened by the still- building drag from rising tariffs - which we expect to push US core CPI inflation above a \(4\%\) ar over the coming three months - and depressed business sentiment (Figure 2). Indeed, our tracker of capex intentions has only modestly recovered from last quarter's slide and continues to align with a pullback.

Next week's August releases are likely to sustain rather than resolve tensions in the macroeconomic outlook. We expect another weak job gain (75k) alongside still solid labor income growth. While we expect a modest rise in the ISM, the large gap between this survey's downbeat signal and the positive PMI is not expected to close.
Figure 3: Global IP and export volumes
Source: CPB, national sources, J.P. Morgan. Details on request.

An expected midyear downshift in global trade and industrial activity is underway (Figure 3). Global IP stalled in the three months through July and export volumes contracted at a \(2.5\%\) ar. Front- loading was most pronounced in Euro area pharmaceuticals and Asia tech, but the unwind in both exports and production has been concentrated in the Euro
area. US tech import demand remains resilient, and there appears to be underlying strength in global capex.

As we gauge the balance between strong underlying tech demand and a coming front- loading hangover, we are raising our sights on current- quarter Asia GDP growth. Last week's upward revisions in Korea and Malaysia were followed by upgrades to Taiwan and Singapore this week. Taiwan remains at the epicenter of this cycle and its revisions are the largest. We now look for a modest \(0.5\%\) ar rise in GDP this quarter (previously \(- 2\%\) ar) and a far smaller cumulative unwind of the \(10\%\) ar surge in 1H25 growth. A similar but more modest adjustment has been made to EMAX overall, where we now look for the region to grow \(2.9\%\) over the four quarters of this year, up from a \(2.1\%\) forecast at midyear.

Even as its sales to the US have collapsed, China has benefitted from the 1H25 global capex pickup through transhipments and sales to other markets. Exports fell less than expected in July and alt- data points to a rebound in August underpinned by non- US sales. We are not, however, upgrading China growth which we continue to expect to slip below a \(3\%\) ar in 2H25. July data suggests domestic demand has slowed more sharply than expected and recent anti- involution efforts may weigh on 2H25 investment. Consistent with this view, we expect only a modest rebound in next week's August manufacturing surveys from their recent slide.

French prime minister Bayrou unexpectedly called a confidence vote this week for September 8, which he looks set to lose. It looks most likely that President Macron will appoint a new prime minister rather than call new lower house elections. It remains unclear why Bayrou is insisting on a \(0.9\%\) of GDP fiscal consolidation next year, almost double that required under EU rules. If new elections were triggered, the most likely outcome in our view would be an RN government backed only by a relative majority in the lower house. We think that RN will align with the fiscal tightening we expect, having moderated its fiscal demands and having voiced support for the EU rules. RN likely would not want to rock the
boat ahead of the 2027 presidential elections.

In line with this view, the spread to German bunds widened just 10bp this week. The region has come a long way from the days when a lack of (conditional) support mechanisms and more fundamental challenges to fiscal orthodoxy resulted in extreme market pressures and spillovers. Governments are keenly aware that the various ECB bond market programs are conditional on fiscal responsibility. As a result, the region has moved to a better equilibrium, with markets exerting discipline without requiring a significant tightening in financial conditions.

With a policy rate of \(2\%\) seen in a "good place", the ECB needs a push from the data to ease. Growth remains resilient, putting the focus on disinflation to jolt the ECB into action. July's minutes showed lingering concern around service prices, but this preceded a weaker July HICP reading and this week's indications from national reports that core prices will rise roughly \(0.15\%\) m/m in next week's August flash. Softer inflation motivates our call for an October cut. In neighboring CEE, core inflation is substantially higher, but Poland stands out with significant downward momentum and a constructive August flash (Figure 4). We still see the NBP on hold next week, but risks skew to a cut.
Figure 4: Europe core inflation
Source: National sources, J.P. Morgan. Details on request.

India's 2Q GDP surged past expectations. While some of the upside surprise was technical - a goods deflator was used to deflate services growth, where inflation runs relatively high - the \(7.8\%\) oya also reflected strong fiscal support and a betterthan- expected gain in manufacturing. However, clouds are gathering as US tariffs of \(50\%\) on India came into effect this week, taking the effective tariff on India to \(34\%\) , the second highest in the world. India's goods trade with the US is small but we see a hit of about \(1\%\) to India GDP if tariffs are sustained at these levels. At greatest risk are labor- intensive sectors where price competition is relatively strong - agriculture and textiles. Next week all eyes will turn to fiscal policy with indirect tax reform on the cards, which should impart some fiscal impulse to the economy.

Africa's disinflation lagged other Edge economies last year due to adjustments in overvalued exchange rates, along with the removal of price subsidies. But inflation is now coming down rapidly and this should allow central banks to embark on large and sustained policy rate cuts. After accumulating FX reserves in prior years, central bank reaction functions also appear to be changing, as they allow capital inflows and/or CA surpluses to drive nominal (and real) exchange rate appreciation and further help disinflation. An example of this came with this week's a larger- than- consensus 200bp cut from Egypt's central bank. The move comes after a soft July CPI print tamed concerns about recent regulated price increases. While some upside inflation risks remain, relatively high real rates in Egypt should allow for a further 300bp of easing this year. We also expect further rate cuts from Ghana (- 600bp) while Nigeria and Zambia are likely to commence rate cuts in 4Q25 and 1Q26, respectively.

Argentine assets have faced mounting pressure due to heightened political risk premiums. Congressional approval of laws undermining fiscal stability, the overturning of presidential vetoes, and recent corruption allegations have collectively pushed real interest rates above a \(2\%\) monthly rate. Stringent monetary conditions are expected to persist at least through the coming election cycle and weigh on economic activity. We have recently downgraded our economic activity forecasts modestly but are encouraged that the pass- through to FX and inflation remains limited. While the near- term effects of elevated real interest rates on public finances are modest, we see a normalization of market conditions as essential to sustain fiscal and monetary stability. In Brazil, the Supreme Court will hold a trial next week on several individuals charged with attempting a coup in January 2023, including former president Jair Bolsonaro. The trial will be closely watched by the U.S. administration, where officials have expressed concern over Bolsonaro's treatment. The outcome may have important implications for the opposition's strategy as it eyes the 2026 election.

We expect the August ISM manufacturing survey to inch up to 49.0 from 48.0 in July, while the final PMI manufacturing composite remains level at 53.0, compared to the flash print of 53.3. The PMI has portrayed a more optimistic outlook for the manufacturing sector since the beginning of the year, whereas the ISM index has declined repeatedly since January, apart from a brief increase in June. The regional Empire, Philadelphia, Kansas City, Dallas and Richmond Fed surveys released so far have improved through the month, with the average composite moving to 51.9 from 51.0 in the prior month.

The manufacturing PMI composite improved by 3.5 points in the flash reading vs. July, with all components contributing to the growth. The measures for output, new export orders, and backlogs of work reached their highest levels in three years, signaling a pickup in activity. While the July ISM print lacked improvement in the headline reading, the production index recovered from a cycle low of 44.0 in April to 51.4 in the latest report. Manufacturing IP has been little changed in recent months after strong readings earlier in the year, possibly partially driven by front- loading efforts by firms ahead of anticipated tariffs. However, the improving signals from the surveys suggest the series could pick up again in the coming months.

Price pressures continue to build in the sector, with the latest PMI input price metric partially erasing the moderation seen through July with a 2.5- point increase in August. The PPI index for intermediate demand materials and components for manufacturing has risen \(3.3\%\) oya, the highest in over three years, and this has also been reflected in the core goods PCE deflator, which picked up to \(1.1\%\) oya in July compared to

\(0.3\%\) in April. The employment index in the PMI report has been volatile since June, with the August print rising by over 4 points, even though in recent months the series has overestimated payroll growth in the industry, which has been contracting.

We expect construction spending to continue contracting going into the second half of the year, with a \(0.3\% m/m\) fall in July, driven by a persistent decline in private residential construction. Single-family construction spending has been deteriorating as homebuilders cut starts and work through elevated inventories of homes amid muted demand. While declining prices and increased use of incentives could help prop up sales, high mortgage rates have been preventing any material uptick in buying activity. In contrast, the volatile multifamily component is set to contribute positively in July, as starts rose \(1.5\% m/m\) during the month.

After a weak start to the year, construction spending on home improvement picked up through 2Q. However, with retail sales for building materials falling by \(1\% m/m\) and a \(0.1\% m/m\) drop in employment across specialty residential trade contractors, home improvement could prove to be a drag on residential construction spending in July. Nonresidential construction spending is also set to fall \(0.2\% m/m\) in July, following a strong run earlier in the decade, as investments in semiconductor facilities were boosted by the CHIPS Act. Data center spending, however, continues to grow robustly, with a \(1.8\% m/m\) increase in June and a \(28\%\) rise over the last 12 months.

We expect job openings in July, as reported in JOLTS, to drop to \(7.250\mathrm{mm}\) from \(7.437\mathrm{mm}\) in June, leading to the job openings rate falling to \(4.3\%\) . Daily job openings reported by

Indeed inched down between the end of June and July, and the employment components on the small business optimism index also declined throughout the month, signaling a drop in job openings. The hires rate has stayed in a narrow range over the last year, though it did slip \(0.2\%\) - pt in the last couple months.

While the overall quits rate has been stable, the accommodation and food services sector has experienced a surge in quits, rising from a recent low of 3.7 in January to 4.9 in June. We recently hypothesized that this could result from increased enforcement of the administration's immigration policies; especially the termination of humanitarian parole programs such as CHNV, which may lead to increased turnover in select industries, although the evidence so far is mixed. Following the spike in separations among government workers at the beginning of the year, caused by DOGE- led efforts to reduce the workforce, the latest reading in this category shows a separation rate of \(1.2\%\) , the lowest since the summer of 2014.

Our auto equity analysts expect light vehicle sales in July to inch down to 16.2mn saar from 16.4mn, based on preliminary data. This would continue to showcase resilient auto sales following the downturn observed in May and June, as the earlier front- loading ahead of April tariffs began to wane. The team recently remarked that the expiration of US federal tax credits on electric vehicles could be contributing to growing demand, as affirmed by increased BEV penetration through July, along with an improved supply of luxury brands that had partially halted shipments since April. Our auto team will revisit its forecast next week as more data becomes available.

The ADP reading of private sector employment had a stark upturn in July rising by 104k, following soft readings since the beginning of the year, including a negative print in June. The July ADP print marked improving payrolls across all sectors, apart from education and health services, which was the main source of growth in the BLS measure of private payroll growth. In a speech on August 28, Fed governor Waller noted that weekly ADP data obtained by the Fed was pointing to renewed weakness in job growth, so August could revert to a weaker print again. Note though that the average absolute error between first prints of ADP and BLS over the last 12 months is 76k.

We anticipate the goods and services trade deficit to widen to \(\) 79.4\(billion in June from\) \ \(60.2\) billion in May, based on already released figures on goods trade. The final trade print would help detangle the impact of any potential surge in gold imports, which are excluded from GDP accounting, from the large \(25\%\) m/m jump in industrial supply goods, causing an outsized widening of the goods trade balance through July. After a weak start to the year, household spending on services in the PCE data has picked up slightly, which could signal an uptick in services imports that have been in contractionary territory over the past two months. Services exports remain weak, weighed down by a lack of foreign demand for tourism and the absence of any material boost from a weakening dollar.

We look for the August ISM services index to rise to 51.0 from 50.1 in July, while the final PMI business activity measure experiences a slight downtick to 55.0 from the flash reading of 55.4. The latest PMI reading saw improvements in both the new business and new export orders indexes, which could signal strengthening services demand after a subdued start to the year, and the general business activity measure has been robust in the last two months. The ISM services composite, in contrast, has been deteriorating since October 2024, with the business activity, new orders, and employment indexes collectively weighing on demand.
The diverging signals between the ISM and PMI prints could partially result from differences in survey scope; the ISM sur

vey includes industries such as wholesale and retail trade, government, construction, mining, and agriculture, which are excluded from the PMI. However, a number of these industries were reported to be growing, so it's hard to conclude that the weaker ISM readings are linked to coverage differences.

Price inflation reported by services surveys remains elevated. The July ISM print recorded a \(\sim 1.5\) - point increase, while the more recent August flash PMI saw input prices moving sideways and output prices ticking up by close to one point from 58.2 in July. The employment measure has been one of the sources of diverging readings between the two surveys: the July ISM employment measure signaled a contraction in payrolls at 46.4, while the PMI counterpart reached 52.5 in the August flash reading, its highest level since the beginning of the year.

We expect nonfarm payrolls rose \(75k\) in August and that the unemployment rate increased from \(4.2\%\) to \(4.3\%\) . We also forecast that average hourly earnings rose \(0.3\% /m/m\) \((3.7\% /ya)\) and that the workweek held at 34.3.

We forecast that both overall and private payrolls rose \(75k\) in August. We assume that federal government payrolls continue to steadily decline: excluding a large 26k cut in May, they've fallen by an average of \(12k\) per month since the start of the Trump administration, and we then expect this will be offset by growth in state and local employment. The administration has signalled that large additional federal layoffs are generally not needed in light of employment declines caused by attrition plus the \(\sim 150k\) employees who took deferred resignations and are set to roll off payrolls starting in October.

For the private sector, job growth was 83k in July and averaged 52k per month over the past 3 months and 85k over the last 6 months. It's likely that breakeven employment has declined well under 100k given low net immigration. There is a possibility that the termination of temporary legal status for large numbers of immigrants, which we discussed recently here, could further depress payroll growth in the near term. However, it remains difficult to guess exactly how quickly these will hit the employment numbers.

Looking across a range of labor indicators there was not much change between July and August. The Conference Board's labor market differential kept falling, from \(11.0\%\) in July to \(9.7\%\) in August, but elsewhere there wasn't a clear trend. The PMI all- industry employment measure improved slightly, the regional Fed surveys were mostly unchanged, Indeed job openings ticked up, and the Census BTOS was better than a year earlier. Initial jobless claims rose 13k between the payroll reference weeks (the week including the \(12^{\mathrm{th}}\) of the month), but the four- week average of claims fell. Continuing jobless claims rose just 8k, and since the latest week has tended to be revised down this year next week's claims report will likely show about no change over the month. In addition, employees working reported by Homebase have a fairly similar change over the month compared to the same month in prior years.

One additional observation comes from a speech this week by Governor Waller. He noted that weekly data that ADP shares with the Fed pointed to "continued deterioration" in the employment trend after the July survey week. That could also signal that the monthly ADP figure due out next week will be soft.

Revisions have been a hot topic ever since the large down- ward revisions that accompanied the July payroll report. Their magnitude was unusually large, but their direction was not, as revisions have been consistently negative over the last few years. Looking at past years, the August release was typically revised up, leading one to discount weakness in the first release, but this trend has reversed in the last few years, at least by the time of the third release. For the already- released July data there is not a clear pattern. In the last couple years there was a downward revision with the second release and a net upward revision by the time of the third release, but this may not be a new pattern. Finally, for the June data, revisions have been consistently negative since 2022. Normally, though, the big downward revisions come with the third
release, whereas this year there was already a large negative revision with the second release, so it is unclear if we are due for further revisions.

Average hourly earnings growth has been reasonably stable since 2024, and so we expect a \(0.3\% /m\) increase, which would represent a pace just a touch slower than the average in the year to July, when earnings rose \(3.9\%\) oya. The recent drop in employment growth could represent a softening labor market that would be consistent both with a slowing in wage growth and a reduction in the workweek, but slack, as captured in the unemployment rate, has not moved much to date.
Source: BLS, J.P. Morgan

For the workweek, we look for no change at \(34.3\) . A drop to \(34.2\) is also possible given the week has fluctuated between \(34.3\) and \(34.2\) repeatedly since early last year. Recently the workweek in transportation and warehousing has increased, possibly linked to trade front- loading, and an eventual decline could put slight downward pressure on the overall workweek.
Average weekly hours Hours, sa, both scales
Source: BLS, J.P. Morgan

The unemployment rate was \(4.24\%\) in July, so it will take only a small increase to have it round up to \(4.3\%\) . The Conference Board consumer confidence survey's labor market differential kept worsening during August, falling from \(11.0\%\) to \(9.7\%\) . On the other hand, continuing jobless claims were roughly flat between the July and August household survey reference weeks. We also think a decline in unemployment among new labor market entrants could restrain any increase, which offers the possibility that the rate will remain at \(4.2\%\) .
Unemployment rate vs. continuing claims to labor force ratio Unemployment rate
Source: Department of Labor, BLS, J.P. Morgan. July assumes \(0.1\% /m\) labor force rise
Unemployment rate vs. Conference Board labor market differential Unemployment rate
Source: BLS, Conference Board, J.P. Morgan

As seen in the figure below, there was a sharp rise in the number of unemployed new labor force entrants in July, with the \(39\% m / m\) rise being one of the largest percentage increases on record. As we discussed in a recent note, this is quite possibly sampling noise that will soon reverse. The data on unemployment by reason is seasonally adjusted separately and does not sum to the official change in the unemployment rate, which makes it challenging to estimate how much a reversal in this series would lower total unemployment. One possible approach is to note that when summing the unemployment data by reason, new entrants accounted for \(60\%\) of the increase. Given the overall unemployment rate rose \(13\mathrm{bps}\) a way of framing this is to estimate that new entrants accounted for \(60\%\) of that \(13\mathrm{bps}\) increase, or \(8\mathrm{bps}\) and that a full reversal would cause the unemployment rate to fall by an equivalent amount.
Unemployed new labor force entrants
Source: BLS, J.P. Morgan

We also look for the participation rate to hold constant at \(62.2\%\) . The participation rate has been steadily falling since 2023. This has primarily reflected declines in participation for workers ages 16- 24 and \(55+\) . Along with the longer- run decline in youth participation there may be some residual seasonality in the last few years: since 2023 the rate has peaked in February and March each year, then declined into the summer, with troughs in July 2023 and August 2024. Were this pattern to repeat this year, it could contribute to a 20- 30bps increase in participation between now and early next year, holding participation constant for other age groups. In the short- term, though, it's possible that youth participation could edge down further in the August report, given the trough was in August last year.
